Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research - Development and innovation of the Barrow Area Information Database (BAID): A cyberinfrastructure that supports arctic science, outreach and education
Award.AbstractNarration: The Barrow Area Information Database (BAID, http://baid.utep.edu) is a regional cyberinfrastructure that offers users access to geospatial information about more than 9,600 research sites in the area. The BAID is an online geospatial information tool used by scientists, land managers, educators, students, subsistence hunters and the general public. The services provide information about scientific research in the region from Barrow to Atqasuk with a suite of online, interative maps and services, including searchable fields and more than 150 data layers describing vegetation, topography, land ownership, ground control points and infrastructure. This proposal will update and upgrade the current services offered via web servers. In addition, a wireless sensor network will provide near real-time meteorological data for the region. Data available through BAID will be made more interoperable and will link to the data archives at the National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC). Detailed climate data with spatial coverage for the region will benefit a broad group of researchers. The project will also develop students who can program, develop, and maintain cyberinfrastructure tools and infrastructure for basic researcher, land managers and land users.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project continued development of the Barrow Area Information Database (BAID, www.barrowmapped.org). As an operational cyberinfrastructure, BAID provides users with tools and systems for sustained access and analysis of current and diverse information and data about the Barrow area in northern Alaska. Our overarching goal was to enhance virtual scientific and other collaboration and to meet the current and growing needs of our user community: Seven key objectives were addressed:

  1. We liaised with BAID-users and Barrow area researchers to identify, prioritize and meet their needs for field data collection, data layer generation, and Differential Global Positioning System (DGPS) surveys and other mapping support. BAID now contains information on the who, what, where, when and why for more than 18,200 research sites established in the Barrow area since the 1950’s. Extensive historical aerial photography has also been compiled for the region.
  2. A suite of BAID web mapping and other applications were developed and offer a faster, user-friendly web interface with improved scalability, functionality and stability. Mapping applications include a simple (for low bandwidth connections) and advanced research sites viewer, a viewer for interacting with a high spatial resolution land cover/wetlands map and historical and modern coastal erosion data, and time series high spatial resolution aerial and satellite imagery.
  3. Aging hardware supporting BAID was replaced and a modern virtual server environment with improved reliability and sustainability was built.
  4. A network of climate stations and coastal camera station was established over the Barrow Peninsular and has been maintained. Following completion of this award, maintenance of these resources have been transitioned to other funded activities to ensure sustained data collection.
  5. The interoperability of BAID with other cyberinfrastructure has been established and/or improved through work flows, web services, and use of controlled vocabularies. We have contributed to the development of new metadata standards and other innovations in data science.
  6. BAID data has been archived at the NSF Arctic Data Center and BAID data products have been used in a range of peer-reviewed science papers, government/agency reports, the media, and several artists and documentary film makers.
  7. The next generation of environmental and data scientists at a leading minority-majority university was trained and extensive interaction with and training of the diverse BAID user community was conducted.

To our knowledge, this project has resulted in the Barrow area being arguably the most well-documented flagship observatory in the Arctic. BAID will permit multiple future generations of science-focused user groups with access to critical information and links to data associated with the rich legacy of scientific effort in the Barrow area of northern Alaska.
